title: AB 130
content: The State of California enacts the following. Section 89724 of the Education Code is amended to appropriate money for the support of the California State University from various sources, including the sale of publications, agreements, student fees, and other specified sources. Money received under Sections 89720 and 89721, or pursuant to Section 2080.8 of the Civil Code, is appropriated without regard to fiscal year. Funds from Section 2080.8 are for student scholarships and loans, with interest used for the same purpose. Funds from Sections 89720 and 89721 can be invested in eligible securities for the same purpose. Money received under Sections 89720 and 89721, or pursuant to Section 2080.8 of the Civil Code, may also be appropriated. Money received under Sections 89720 and 89721, or pursuant to Section 2080.8 of the Civil Code, may be invested in mutual funds or real estate investment trusts, subject to regulatory authority. Interest and earnings from these investments shall be used for purposes established by the trustees. The money received shall augment the support appropriation to the California State University for the applicable fiscal year. All money received from the sale or disposition of real or personal property acquired by a California State University campus through gift, devise, or donation is appropriated to the trustees for capital outlay for property acquisition and improvement, in addition to any other funds allocated by the Legislature. The trustees must obtain approval from the Director of Finance before spending any money appropriated by the Legislature. The funds will supplement the support or capital outlay appropriation of the California State University. The trustees can deposit grants, revenues, and funds for research and special projects in the California State University Special Projects Fund in the State Treasury. These funds are appropriated for the operation and development of various projects at the university. The trustees have authority to establish rules for the California State University Special Projects Fund, including reimbursements for space and services. Expenditures must follow set rules without prior approval, and investments are limited to eligible securities. The trustees of the California State University have the authority to invest money received under specific codes in mutual funds or real estate investment trusts. They may also invest in securities not listed in the Government Code with the advice of a committee. The trustees of the California State University have the authority to invest money in securities or investments not listed in the Government Code. A committee with investment expertise, excluding trustees or university employees, advises on investments. The total amount invested in such securities shall not exceed specified amounts for each fiscal year. The trustees of the California State University receive quarterly investment performance reports and distribute an annual report to the Legislature and the Department of Finance. Reports include investment returns, benchmarks, holdings, market values, and fees. Additional earnings from investments not listed in the Government Code must be used for capital outlay or maintenance. Trustees cannot request funds to compensate for investment losses from such investments. The trustees of the California State University cannot use investment losses from securities not listed in the Government Code to justify raising student tuition or fees.
